Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the This type of material has attracted much attention and showed a variety of interesting phenomena according to the composition of lanthanides and transition metals [11, 12]. Relatively high Tc for the other ruthenium phosphide superconductors were found in ZrRuP (Tc = 13 K) [13] and LaRu4P12 (Tc = 7.2 K) [14].

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 Results and Discussion 3.1 Crystal structure The powder X-ray diﬀraction patterns for both polycrys- talline and single crystal samples could be indexed as a Ru7B3 phase with the space group of P63mc. The lattice constants of the single crystal Ru7B3 were determined to be approximately a ¼ 7:441ð5Þ A˚ and c ¼ 4:700ð4Þ A˚ , respec- tively.

Superconducting State of the Binary Boride Ru7B3 with the Noncentrosymmetric Crystal Structure Naoki KASE and Jun AKIMITSU Department of Physics and Mathematics, Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1 Fuchinobe, Sagamihara, Kanagawa 229-8558 3.3 Electrical resistivity Figure 4 shows electrical resistivity as a function of temperature between 2.0 and 300 K. The onset and zero- resistivity temperatures were observed to be 2.95 and 2.8 K, respectively. Transition width can be deﬁned as the temper- ature interval between 10 and 90% of the transition and is estimated to be approximately 0.1 K. The sharp super- conducting transition indicates the high purity of the sample.

High-pressure synchrotron-diffraction study of the superconducting spin-ladder compounds „Sr, M…14Cu24O41 „M5Ca, Ba, Nd… Ste´phanie Pachot and Pierre Bordet Laboratoire de Cristallographie CNRS, Boıˆte Postale 166, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 9, France Robert J. Cava The effect of applied pressure and lattice anomaly on the physical and superconducting properties of the (Sr142x ,M x)Cu24O41 compounds may be discussed on the basis of the present results and already reported structural and physical measurements.5–7 The main effect of the sub- stitution of Ca for Sr and of applied pressure is a strong decrease of the b cell parameter, which corresponds to an increased coupling between the ladder and chain layers, and to a charge transfer from the chains to the ladders. However, the substitution effect alone is not sufﬁcient to induce superconductivity at low temperature, and an additional external pressure has to be applied, with appearance of the superconducting state at '3 GPa for the ~Sr0.4 , Ca13.6!Cu24O41 compound, which corre- sponds to a cell parameter b'12.15 Å.

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the Ruthenium phosphide LaRu2P2 was found to be superconducting at about 4 K more than 20 years ago [8]. Similar to the cuprates, both the iron-based superconductors and LaRu2P2 have a two-dimensional crystal structure.

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the The magnitude of the upper and lower critical ﬁelds was estimated to be about 1140 and 230 Oe at zero temperature, which is of the same order of magnitude as the other conventional ThCr2Si2-type superconductors. The coherent length and penetration depth are about 54 nm and 80 nm, respectively.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The bottom panel is the powder x-ray diffraction pattern (small circle symbols) compared to a single crystal diffraction pattern (solid line) obtained using an x-ray beam perpendicular to the 00l plane. ducting with a transition temperature Tc of 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Although the zero-ﬁeld data characterize β-IrSn4 well as a s-wave weakly coupled type-I superconductor in a dirty limit, from an estimation of some thermodynamic parameters we arrive at a conclusion that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a type-II superconductor in a clean limit with an assumption of a non-spherical Fermi surface.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In order to get some information on the strength of the electron–phonon coupling we estimate the average electron–phonon coupling constant ¯λe–ph using the McMillan equation [14]: ¯λe–ph = 1.04 + µ∗ln(2D/1.45Tc) (1 −0.62µ∗) ln(2D/1.45Tc) −1.04 (2) where µ∗is the Coulomb pseudopotential, usually assumed to be between 0.1 and 0.15 [14, 15]. For µ∗= 0.15, 2D = 221 K and Tc ≈0.9 K, equation (2) yields ¯λe–ph = 0.5, suggestive of a weak electron–phonon coupling in β-IrSn4.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The solid line presents the exponential function given by the BCS theory Cel(T) = AγnTc exp(−10/kBT), with A = 12.8 and 10/kB = 1.51 K. The bulk nature of superconductivity in β-IrSn4 is evidenced by a clear peak in the Cp(T)/T dependence. The critical temperature Tc = 0.85 K, taken as the middle point of the 1Cp(T)/T jump, agrees fairly with that deduced from the resistivity.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the To summarize, we have grown single crystals of inter- metallic compound β-IrSn4, crystallizing in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure. We found a superconducting transition Tc(0T) = 0.9 ± 0.05 K and an upper critical magnetic ﬁeld µ0Hc2(0) ∼8 mT.

VOLUME 81, NUMBER 25 P H Y S I C A L R E V I E W L E T T E R S 21 DECEMBER 1998 Normal-State Resistivity Anisotropy in Underdoped RBa2Cu3O61x Crystals A. N. Lavrov,* M. Yu. Kameneva, and L. P. Kozeeva The salient consequence of charge conﬁnement is a possibility of superconductivity owing to interlayer pair tunneling [4,5]. Important exceptions from this straightforward pic- ture were however found, and the best known one is YBa2Cu3O7 (Y-123) which is a 90-K superconductor, but possesses a metallic out-of-plane conductivity [7].

VOLUME 81, NUMBER 25 P H Y S I C A L R E V I E W L E T T E R S 21 DECEMBER 1998 Normal-State Resistivity Anisotropy in Underdoped RBa2Cu3O61x Crystals A. N. Lavrov,* M. Yu. Kameneva, and L. P. Kozeeva In the RBa2Cu3O61x system, superconductivity mostly hides the low-T region and the normal-state resistiv- ity can be measured down to fairly low temperatures only in a narrow doping range in the vicinity of the antiferromagnetic-superconducting (AFM-SC) phase boundary. For the sample with x ø 0.41, rc monotonically decreases within a wide temperature range from 127 K down to Tc ø 19 K. A tendency of rc to saturate is apparent for x ø 0.49 as well, but for such and higher doping levels the rc crossover is masked, because Tm quickly decreases with doping, while superconductivity in its turn hides the larger temperature range.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Rietveld reﬁnement of powder XRD data conﬁrms that Re24Ti5 crystallizes in the α-Mn structure. All measured quantities demonstrate a bulk superconducting transition at Tc = 5.8 K. Our low-temperature speciﬁc heat data measured down to 0.5 K yield a Sommerfeld coefﬁcient γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, which implies a high density of states at the Fermi level.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER In this respect, Re24Ti5 would provide an opportunity to search for the existence of a mixture of spin singlet and spin triplet states in the SC phase of the noncentrosymmetric compounds. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and charac- terization of Re24Ti5, which exhibits a distinct bulk SC transition at Tc ≃5.8 K. Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Rietveld reﬁnement of powder XRD data conﬁrms that Re24Ti5 crystallizes in the α-Mn structure. All measured quantities demonstrate a bulk superconducting transition at Tc = 5.8 K. Our low-temperature speciﬁc heat data measured down to 0.5 K yield a Sommerfeld coefﬁcient γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, which implies a high density of states at the Fermi level.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER We thus displayed the plot of C/T versus T2 at H = 0 and 5 T in ﬁgure 8, with a solid curve representing the best ﬁt to the experimental data. Such a ﬁt yields γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, β = 1.47 mJ mol−1 K−4, and δ = 0.0049 mJ mol−1 K−6 for Re24Ti5.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Karki and coworkers have reported a small value of A/γ 2 = 0.24a0, where a0 = 10−5 µ cm mol2 K2 mJ−2 for Re23.8Nb5.2 [9]. Taking A = 0.022 µ cm K−2 and γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, we found A/γ 2 = 0.17a0 for Re24Ti5, lower than those in typical electronic correlated systems which usually have a magnitude of a0 for A/γ 2.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In order to get some information on the strength of the electron–phonon coupling we estimate the average electron–phonon coupling constant ¯λe–ph using the McMillan equation [14]: ¯λe–ph = 1.04 + µ∗ln(2D/1.45Tc) (1 −0.62µ∗) ln(2D/1.45Tc) −1.04 (2) where µ∗is the Coulomb pseudopotential, usually assumed to be between 0.1 and 0.15 [14, 15]. For µ∗= 0.15, 2D = 221 K and Tc ≈0.9 K, equation (2) yields ¯λe–ph = 0.5, suggestive of a weak electron–phonon coupling in β-IrSn4.

The incommensurate A2 ratio between the Cu-Cu separation in both types of layers resulting from this arrange- PHYSICAL REVIEW B 1 MAY 1999-II VOLUME 59, NUMBER 18 PRB 59 0163-1829/99/59~18!/12048~6!/$15.00 12 048 ©1999 The American Physical Society ment, leads to a composite type of structure, which in a ﬁrst approximation can be described by using two orthorhombic unit cells with parameters: al'11.4 Å, bl'13.0 Å, and cl '3.92 Å for the Sr~Cu2O3!Sr ladder-containing slabs, and ac5al , bc5bl , and cc'2.75 Å'7/103cl for the chain lay- ers.

High-pressure synchrotron-diffraction study of the superconducting spin-ladder compounds „Sr, M…14Cu24O41 „M5Ca, Ba, Nd… Ste´phanie Pachot and Pierre Bordet Laboratoire de Cristallographie CNRS, Boıˆte Postale 166, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 9, France Robert J. Cava The effect of applied pressure and lattice anomaly on the physical and superconducting properties of the (Sr142x ,M x)Cu24O41 compounds may be discussed on the basis of the present results and already reported structural and physical measurements.5–7 The main effect of the sub- stitution of Ca for Sr and of applied pressure is a strong decrease of the b cell parameter, which corresponds to an increased coupling between the ladder and chain layers, and to a charge transfer from the chains to the ladders. However, the substitution effect alone is not sufﬁcient to induce superconductivity at low temperature, and an additional external pressure has to be applied, with appearance of the superconducting state at '3 GPa for the ~Sr0.4 , Ca13.6!Cu24O41 compound, which corre- sponds to a cell parameter b'12.15 Å.

Cava Superconductivity was detected in a compound containing spin ladders by Uehara et al.,4 who measured the resistivity as a function of pressure and temperature in the (Sr142x ,Cax)Cu24O41 compounds. These authors reported the appearance of a superconducting transition in the 3–5 GPa range, with a maximum transition temperature of about 12 K, in samples with a large calcium concentration (x 513.6).

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the Besides iron arsenide compounds, earlier works had already found other superconductors with the same crystal structure as BaFe2As2. Ruthenium phosphide LaRu2P2 was found to be superconducting at about 4 K more than 20 years ago [8].

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the This type of material has attracted much attention and showed a variety of interesting phenomena according to the composition of lanthanides and transition metals [11, 12]. Relatively high Tc for the other ruthenium phosphide superconductors were found in ZrRuP (Tc = 13 K) [13] and LaRu4P12 (Tc = 7.2 K) [14].

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the The value of the residual resistivity is much smaller than that in 122 iron-based superconductors. The critical temperature determined from the midpoint of the resistive transition is 3.7 K. The 10–90% width in zero ﬁeld is 0.1 K as shown in the upper inset of ﬁgure 1.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi The thermoelectric properties of the PbBi2Te4 sample were measured at ambient pressure and the electrical resistance was also evaluated under high pressure using a diamond anvil cell with boron-doped diamond electrodes. The resistance decreased with increasing of the pressure, and pressure-induced superconducting transitions were discovered at 2.5 K under 10 GPa.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi The resistance decreased with increasing of the pressure, and pressure-induced superconducting transitions were discovered at 2.5 K under 10 GPa. The maximum superconducting transition temperature increased up to 8.4 K at 21.7 GPa.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi Experimentally, a single crystal of SnBi2Se4 exhibited an insulator-to-metal transition under 11 GPa [6], in a good agreement with the theoretical prediction. Moreover, a pressure-induced superconductivity was observed with maximum superconducting transition temperature (Tc) of 5.4 K under 63 GPa in accordance with our scenario.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi The Tc onset was enhanced from 3.4 K under 13.3 GPa to 8.1 K under 18.0 GPa. In the higher pressure region, the maxi- mum Tc onset and Tc zero were 8.4 K and 7.9 K under 21.7 GPa, respectively.

In a higher pressure region above 18.0 GPa, we observed a Tc jump from 3.4 K to 8.4 K. The Tc jump indicates a possibility of appearance of sec- ond superconducting phase.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The bottom panel is the powder x-ray diffraction pattern (small circle symbols) compared to a single crystal diffraction pattern (solid line) obtained using an x-ray beam perpendicular to the 00l plane. ducting with a transition temperature Tc of 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Although the zero-ﬁeld data characterize β-IrSn4 well as a s-wave weakly coupled type-I superconductor in a dirty limit, from an estimation of some thermodynamic parameters we arrive at a conclusion that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a type-II superconductor in a clean limit with an assumption of a non-spherical Fermi surface.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the In order to get some information on the strength of the electron–phonon coupling we estimate the average electron–phonon coupling constant ¯λe–ph using the McMillan equation [14]: ¯λe–ph = 1.04 + µ∗ln(2D/1.45Tc) (1 −0.62µ∗) ln(2D/1.45Tc) −1.04 (2) where µ∗is the Coulomb pseudopotential, usually assumed to be between 0.1 and 0.15 [14, 15]. For µ∗= 0.15, 2D = 221 K and Tc ≈0.9 K, equation (2) yields ¯λe–ph = 0.5, suggestive of a weak electron–phonon coupling in β-IrSn4.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The solid line presents the exponential function given by the BCS theory Cel(T) = AγnTc exp(−10/kBT), with A = 12.8 and 10/kB = 1.51 K. The bulk nature of superconductivity in β-IrSn4 is evidenced by a clear peak in the Cp(T)/T dependence. The critical temperature Tc = 0.85 K, taken as the middle point of the 1Cp(T)/T jump, agrees fairly with that deduced from the resistivity.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the A similar behavior has been observed in the type-I superconductors (Sc, Lu)Ga3 [4] and LaRhSi3 [7], thus strongly supporting a type-I superconductivity in β-IrSn4. Second, perhaps most surprisingly, the critical temperature increases a little, up to 0.94 K, on the application of a ﬁeld of 1.5 mT.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Thus, we are dealing with the fact that both RKW and the effective mass of ∼3 me are enhanced in β-IrSn4. Finally, an interesting outcome is obtained from comparison of the studied compound with the intermetallic compound AuSn4, which was previously reported to undergo a superconducting transition at Tc = 2.4 K [26, 27].

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the To summarize, we have grown single crystals of inter- metallic compound β-IrSn4, crystallizing in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure. We found a superconducting transition Tc(0T) = 0.9 ± 0.05 K and an upper critical magnetic ﬁeld µ0Hc2(0) ∼8 mT.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto We studied structural and electrical properties under high pressure and low temperature for a S51/2 Heisen- berg two-leg ladder compound Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d. It showed a superconducting transition above 3 GPa with a maximum Tc of 13 K. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase survives at least up to 9 GPa and down to 7 K without decomposition or phase transition, indicating that it is responsible for the observed superconductivity.

Matsumoto At ambient pressure, the r2T curve shows a broad hump with two metal-semiconductor-like transitions near 160 and 50 K. This strange and characteristic behavior has been ob- served in samples with the Ca content x>13.0. The ﬁrst increase near 160 K reminds us of an incomplete Peierls- transition observed in a quasi-1D system such as NbSe3.56–59 The resistivity of NbSe3 shows a downturn soon after the transition because of incomplete nesting of the Fermi surface owing to two-dimensional character in its electronic struc- FIG.

Tc increases up to ;13 K at 5 GPa, and then is suppressed in the metallic state above 5 GPa.

Kozeeva The salient consequence of charge conﬁnement is a possibility of superconductivity owing to interlayer pair tunneling [4,5]. Important exceptions from this straightforward pic- ture were however found, and the best known one is YBa2Cu3O7 (Y-123) which is a 90-K superconductor, but possesses a metallic out-of-plane conductivity [7].

Actually, apart from the resistivity scale, similar behavior (rab ~ T2 and a crossover in rc at ø120 K) was observed in the noncuprate layered system Sr2RuO4 [15], and the anisotropy saturation at low T was reported for La22xSrxCuO4 [3].

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Rietveld reﬁnement of powder XRD data conﬁrms that Re24Ti5 crystallizes in the α-Mn structure. All measured quantities demonstrate a bulk superconducting transition at Tc = 5.8 K. Our low-temperature speciﬁc heat data measured down to 0.5 K yield a Sommerfeld coefﬁcient γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, which implies a high density of states at the Fermi level.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER In this respect, Re24Ti5 would provide an opportunity to search for the existence of a mixture of spin singlet and spin triplet states in the SC phase of the noncentrosymmetric compounds. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and charac- terization of Re24Ti5, which exhibits a distinct bulk SC transition at Tc ≃5.8 K. Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility for Re24Ti5 is shown in ﬁgure 2. The observed diamagnetic behavior below the transition temperature Tc ≃ 5.8 K conﬁrms the occurrence of superconductivity in this material.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The ﬁtting result is quite satisfactory, yielding an isotropic gap 1/kB of about 10.6 K for Re24Ti5. Also the superconducting transition temperature of 5.74 K revealed from the ﬁt is close to those from the transport and magnetic measurements.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER According to our Ce(T) analysis, Re24Ti5 is better described as an ordinary s-wave superconductor, indicating that a mixture of the spin singlet and triplet states in the SC phase driven by the ASOC effect is invisible. This result is likely due to a small band splitting lifted by ASOC as compared to the transition temperature Tc ≃5.8 K for Re24Ti5.

Electrical resistivity was measured by a conventional DC four-probe method in a temperature range of 2.0–300 K under zero and various applied magnetic ﬁelds.

High-pressure synchrotron-diffraction study of the superconducting spin-ladder compounds „Sr, M…14Cu24O41 „M5Ca, Ba, Nd… Ste´phanie Pachot and Pierre Bordet Laboratoire de Cristallographie CNRS, Boıˆte Postale 166, 38042 Grenoble Cedex 9, France Robert J. Cava Superconductivity was detected in a compound containing spin ladders by Uehara et al.,4 who measured the resistivity as a function of pressure and temperature in the (Sr142x ,Cax)Cu24O41 compounds. These authors reported the appearance of a superconducting transition in the 3–5 GPa range, with a maximum transition temperature of about 12 K, in samples with a large calcium concentration (x 513.6).

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the Besides iron arsenide compounds, earlier works had already found other superconductors with the same crystal structure as BaFe2As2. Ruthenium phosphide LaRu2P2 was found to be superconducting at about 4 K more than 20 years ago [8].

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the This type of material has attracted much attention and showed a variety of interesting phenomena according to the composition of lanthanides and transition metals [11, 12]. Relatively high Tc for the other ruthenium phosphide superconductors were found in ZrRuP (Tc = 13 K) [13] and LaRu4P12 (Tc = 7.2 K) [14].

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the This type of material has attracted much attention and showed a variety of interesting phenomena according to the composition of lanthanides and transition metals [11, 12]. Relatively high Tc for the other ruthenium phosphide superconductors were found in ZrRuP (Tc = 13 K) [13] and LaRu4P12 (Tc = 7.2 K) [14].

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the Figure 1 shows the temperature dependence of the resistivity for the current ﬂowing in the ab plane of LaRu2P2. The value of ρab at 300 K is about 110 μ cm and the residual resistivity is about 8.9 μ cm, which leads to the residual resistivity ratio (RRR) = ρab(300 K)/ρab(4 K) of approximately 12.4.

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the The value of the residual resistivity is much smaller than that in 122 iron-based superconductors. The critical temperature determined from the midpoint of the resistive transition is 3.7 K. The 10–90% width in zero ﬁeld is 0.1 K as shown in the upper inset of ﬁgure 1.

The transition temperature falls below 1.8 K after applying 1000 Oe magnetic ﬁeld both along and perpendicular to the ab plane.

The value of Hc1 is about 114 and 100 Oe at 1.8 K for H parallel and perpendicular to the plane, respectively.

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the We deﬁned the irreversibility ﬁeld Hirr(T) as the ﬁeld below which there is an observable difference of the magnetization for increasing and decreasing magnetic ﬁeld [16]. The value of Hirr at 1.8 K is 550 and 530 Oe (550 and 544 Oe considering the demagnetization correction) for the ﬁeld parallel and perpendicular to the plane, respectively.

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the The value of Hirr at 1.8 K is 550 and 530 Oe (550 and 544 Oe considering the demagnetization correction) for the ﬁeld parallel and perpendicular to the plane, respectively. The value of Hirr for different ﬁeld orientations at 1.8 K are almost the same.

Superconductor Science and Technology Isotropic superconductivity in LaRu2P2 with the It is the same order of magnitude as the electron-doped iron-based superconductor BaFe2−xCoxAs2 [5]. Within the weak-coupling BCS theory, the upper critical ﬁeld at T = 0 K can be determined by the Werthamer–Helfand–Hohenberg (WHH) equation [17] Hc2(0) = 0.693[−(dHc2/dT )]TcTc.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi The thermoelectric properties of the PbBi2Te4 sample were measured at ambient pressure and the electrical resistance was also evaluated under high pressure using a diamond anvil cell with boron-doped diamond electrodes. The resistance decreased with increasing of the pressure, and pressure-induced superconducting transitions were discovered at 2.5 K under 10 GPa.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi The resistance decreased with increasing of the pressure, and pressure-induced superconducting transitions were discovered at 2.5 K under 10 GPa. The maximum superconducting transition temperature increased up to 8.4 K at 21.7 GPa.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi Experimentally, a single crystal of SnBi2Se4 exhibited an insulator-to-metal transition under 11 GPa [6], in a good agreement with the theoretical prediction. Moreover, a pressure-induced superconductivity was observed with maximum superconducting transition temperature (Tc) of 5.4 K under 63 GPa in accordance with our scenario.

The sample was heated at 500 °C for 50 h for homo- genization of PbBi2Te4 phase.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi All observed peaks were well indexed to trigonal R-3m structure with lattice con- stants of a = b = 4.42 Å and c = 41.57 Å, without any impurity peaks. Here we note that if the sample is synthesized without the annealing process at 500 °C for 50 h which is described in the experimental section, the PbBi4Te7 contamination appears.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi Consequently, the thermoelectric properties of the power factor and ﬁgure of merit were dramatically increased in PbBi2Te4 compared to SnBi2Se4. The highest values of the power factor ~100 μWm−1 K−2 and ﬁgure of merit ~ 0.02 were obtained at 300 K. This tendency of high thermo- electric performance would be originated from the ﬂat band with the small band gap, which is equiva- lent to the electronic state in SnBi2Se4 under high pressure [6].

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Intermetallic IrSn4 binary crystallizes in three modiﬁca- tions; the low-temperature form, so-called α-IrSn4, adopts the trigonal IrGe4-type structure (space group P3121) [8], the high-temperature form, β-IrSn4 has the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) [9], and the high-pressure form, HP-IrSn4, possesses the orthorhombic PtSn4-type structure (space group Ccca) [10, 11]. To the best of our knowledge, only α-IrSn4 was reported to be a Pauli paramagnet and non-superconducting down to 2 K [8], whereas none of physical properties of β-IrSn4 and HP-IrSn4 have been reported yet.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The bottom panel is the powder x-ray diffraction pattern (small circle symbols) compared to a single crystal diffraction pattern (solid line) obtained using an x-ray beam perpendicular to the 00l plane. ducting with a transition temperature Tc of 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Although the zero-ﬁeld data characterize β-IrSn4 well as a s-wave weakly coupled type-I superconductor in a dirty limit, from an estimation of some thermodynamic parameters we arrive at a conclusion that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a type-II superconductor in a clean limit with an assumption of a non-spherical Fermi surface.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the If β-IrSn4 is considered as a type-II superconductor then one can estimate the lower critical ﬁeld µ0Hc1 and the upper critical ﬁeld µ0Hc2. µ0Hc1 = 3 mT, if is deﬁned as the ﬁeld where the deviation of the M(H) curve from linearity in the Meissner state sets in, while µ0Hc2 = 6.5 mT at 0.5 K, determined as the intersection between linear interpolations of the magnetization in the superconducting and normal states.

The temperature dependence of ρ(T) indicates that this intermetallic is a good metal. At room temperature the resistivity amounts to 80 µ cm and decreases to approximately 3 µ cm at 1 K. A large residual resistivity ratio RRR = 27, sharp superconducting transition and small residual resistivity value manifest the good sample quality and negligible scattering by defects and impurities.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the The solid line presents the exponential function given by the BCS theory Cel(T) = AγnTc exp(−10/kBT), with A = 12.8 and 10/kB = 1.51 K. The bulk nature of superconductivity in β-IrSn4 is evidenced by a clear peak in the Cp(T)/T dependence. The critical temperature Tc = 0.85 K, taken as the middle point of the 1Cp(T)/T jump, agrees fairly with that deduced from the resistivity.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the A similar behavior has been observed in the type-I superconductors (Sc, Lu)Ga3 [4] and LaRhSi3 [7], thus strongly supporting a type-I superconductivity in β-IrSn4. Second, perhaps most surprisingly, the critical temperature increases a little, up to 0.94 K, on the application of a ﬁeld of 1.5 mT.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Similarly to the case of LaRhSi3 [7] one describes the ﬁeld dependence of the Cp(H)/T data by the exponential function Cp(H)/T = γ (0.4 K) + A × exp(−H∗/H), where γ (0.4 K), A and µ0H∗are ﬁtting parameters. The best ﬁt for data collected in magnetic ﬁelds below 7 mT gives γ (0.4 K) = 3.9 mJ mol−1 K−2, A = 15.8 mJ mol−1 K−2 and µ0H∗= 9.5 mT.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Thus, we are dealing with the fact that both RKW and the effective mass of ∼3 me are enhanced in β-IrSn4. Finally, an interesting outcome is obtained from comparison of the studied compound with the intermetallic compound AuSn4, which was previously reported to undergo a superconducting transition at Tc = 2.4 K [26, 27].

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the To summarize, we have grown single crystals of inter- metallic compound β-IrSn4, crystallizing in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure. We found a superconducting transition Tc(0T) = 0.9 ± 0.05 K and an upper critical magnetic ﬁeld µ0Hc2(0) ∼8 mT.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Matsumoto At ambient pressure, the r2T curve shows a broad hump with two metal-semiconductor-like transitions near 160 and 50 K. This strange and characteristic behavior has been ob- served in samples with the Ca content x>13.0. The ﬁrst increase near 160 K reminds us of an incomplete Peierls- transition observed in a quasi-1D system such as NbSe3.56–59 The resistivity of NbSe3 shows a downturn soon after the transition because of incomplete nesting of the Fermi surface owing to two-dimensional character in its electronic struc- FIG.

Matsumoto However, Sr4Ca10Cu24O411d did not show superconductivity up to 8.5 GPa.61 As shown in Table I, both the a and c axis shrink in nearly the same percentage after the Ca substitution, whereas pressure induces, in the high-temperature region, more aniso- tropic intraplane shrinkage with a larger percentage along the c axis than along the a axis. Expecting direct observation of the Peierls transition, we carried out electron-diffraction measurements around 100 K, but no evidence for it was obtained.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto Expecting direct observation of the Peierls transition, we carried out electron-diffraction measurements around 100 K, but no evidence for it was obtained. In the temperature de- pendence of the b axis, however, we found an anomalous behavior near 150 K where the b axis does not change smoothly as a function of temperature, which cannot be in- terpreted using the classical Gru¨neisen’s equation of state.62 If there is really a breaking point, it means an abrupt change of the thermal-expansion coefﬁcient and the presence of a second-order phase transition.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto In the temperature de- pendence of the b axis, however, we found an anomalous behavior near 150 K where the b axis does not change smoothly as a function of temperature, which cannot be in- terpreted using the classical Gru¨neisen’s equation of state.62 If there is really a breaking point, it means an abrupt change of the thermal-expansion coefﬁcient and the presence of a second-order phase transition. This anomaly may correspond to the increase of resistivity near 160 K. We need, however, more detailed studies to clarify this point.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto The approach to the T-linear dependence from the T-square-like one near 300 K may be explained in terms of antiferromagnetic spin scattering using Fermi-liquid theo- ries as well as that for 2D high-Tc cuprates.63–65 According to the self-consistent renormalization theory, the r(T) is pro- portional to ;xQ5pT2;T2/(T1T)5T/T1 ~xQ is a staggered susceptibility, T1 is a nuclear spin-lattice relaxation time!. Since T1 approaches to be constant with increasing temperature,66 r(T) is proportional to T at the high- temperature limit.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto V. CONCLUSIONS We studied the x-ray diffraction and electrical resistivity in a composite crystal Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d under high pres- sure and low temperature to discuss the nature of the elec- tronic state and pressure-induced superconductivity from crystallographic aspects. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase sur- vives at least for P<9 GPa and T>7 K indicating that it is responsible for superconductivity observed only under high pressure.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto The r-T curves in the normal state above 5 GPa obey a power law of tem- perature in the wide range of temperature between 7 and over 200 K, suggesting that carriers are mainly scattered by spin ﬂuctuation as well as in 2D high-Tc cuprates. Tc increases up to ;13 K at 5 GPa, and then is suppressed in the metallic state above 5 GPa.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER In this respect, Re24Ti5 would provide an opportunity to search for the existence of a mixture of spin singlet and spin triplet states in the SC phase of the noncentrosymmetric compounds. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and charac- terization of Re24Ti5, which exhibits a distinct bulk SC transition at Tc ≃5.8 K. Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Experimental results and discussion A nominally stoichiometric Re24Ti5 sample was prepared from 99.997% Re and 99.95% Ti by mixing appropriate amounts of elemental metals. The resulting ingot was annealed in a vacuum-sealed quartz tube at 800 ◦C for ﬁve days, followed by furnace cooling.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility for Re24Ti5 is shown in ﬁgure 2. The observed diamagnetic behavior below the transition temperature Tc ≃ 5.8 K conﬁrms the occurrence of superconductivity in this material.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The observed temperature dependence of the electrical resistivity for Re24Ti5 is displayed in ﬁgure 3. The normal state resistivity between 6.5 and 14 K can be described well by a power law ρ(T) = ρo + AT2, (1) where ρo is the residual resistivity and A is the temperature coefﬁcient of the electric resistivity.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Electrical resistivity as a function of temperature for Re24Ti5. Inset: a plot of ρ versus T2, showing a linear relation between 6.5 and 14 K. yielding ρo = 214.8 µ cm and A = 0.022 µ cm K−2.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER It is instructive to mention that the electron–electron scattering rate at low temperatures should grow as T2 in the Fermi liquid picture while the residual resistivity ρo may arise from electron scattering due to domain boundaries and/or defects. The value of ρo provides an estimate of the residual resistivity ratio (RRR, ρ (300 K)/ρo) of about 1.3 for Re24Ti5.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER No anomalous feature at or below Tc can be detected to the lowest measured temperature, indicating that the heat transport is insensitive to the electron condensation in Re24Ti5. However, κ(T) shows a clear shoulder near 50 K, commonly seen in solids at low temperatures due to phonon processes.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER The superconducting transition of Re24Ti5 manifests itself by the abrupt drop in S, as indicated in the inset of ﬁgure 5. The Seebeck coefﬁcient develops a broad minimum at around 70 K which is ascribed to the phonon-drag effect.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Such a ﬁt yields γ = 111.8 mJ mol−1 K−2, β = 1.47 mJ mol−1 K−4, and δ = 0.0049 mJ mol−1 K−6 for Re24Ti5. Furthermore, the Debye temperature θD of 428 K can be evaluated from β using the relation θD = (12π4RZ/5β)1/3, where R = Figure 7.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER We thus employed the BCS formula for Ce(T) to ﬁt the result of Ce/T with the ﬁtting curve also displayed in ﬁgure 9. The ﬁtting result is quite satisfactory, yielding an isotropic gap 1/kB of about 10.6 K for Re24Ti5.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER According to our Ce(T) analysis, Re24Ti5 is better described as an ordinary s-wave superconductor, indicating that a mixture of the spin singlet and triplet states in the SC phase driven by the ASOC effect is invisible. This result is likely due to a small band splitting lifted by ASOC as compared to the transition temperature Tc ≃5.8 K for Re24Ti5.

The evolution of the cell parameters as a function of pressure of ﬁve samples of the spin-ladder compounds (Sr, M)14Cu24O41, with M5Ca, Ba, Nd has been investigated up to '10 GPa by high-pressure synchrotron x-ray diffraction on the ID9 beam line of the ESRF.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the For µ0Hc c = 8.1 mT this results as ξab = 206 nm. Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the To summarize, we have grown single crystals of inter- metallic compound β-IrSn4, crystallizing in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure. We found a superconducting transition Tc(0T) = 0.9 ± 0.05 K and an upper critical magnetic ﬁeld µ0Hc2(0) ∼8 mT.

Science and Technology of Advanced Materials ISSN: 1468-6996 (Print) 1878-5514 (Online) Journal homepage: www.tandfonline.com/journals/tsta20 Data-driven exploration of new pressure-induced superconductivity in PbBi2Te4 Ryo Matsumoto, Zhufeng Hou, Masanori Nagao, Shintaro Adachi, Hiroshi Consequently, the thermoelectric properties of the power factor and ﬁgure of merit were dramatically increased in PbBi2Te4 compared to SnBi2Se4. The highest values of the power factor ~100 μWm−1 K−2 and ﬁgure of merit ~ 0.02 were obtained at 300 K. This tendency of high thermo- electric performance would be originated from the ﬂat band with the small band gap, which is equiva- lent to the electronic state in SnBi2Se4 under high pressure [6].

Takeya, Seiki Komiya, and Yoichi Ando† Central Research Institute of Electric Power Industry, Komae, Tokyo 201-8511, Japan ~Received 20 May 2002; revised manuscript received 11 September 2002; published 4 March 2003! Both ab-plane and c-axis thermal conductivities (kab and kc) of lightly doped La22xSrxCuO4 ~LSCO! and EXPERIMENTS The single crystals of LSCO and LCZO are grown by the traveling-solvent ﬂoating-zone technique, and carefully an- nealed in ﬂowing pure He gas to remove the excess oxygen.20 After the crystallographic axes are determined by using an x-ray Laue analysis, the crystals are cut into rectan- gular thin platelets with the typical sizes of 2.530.5 30.15 mm3, where the c axis is perpendicular or parallel to the platelet with an accuracy of 1°. The thermal conductivity k is measured in the temperature range of 2–300 K using a steady-state technique;21–23 above 150 K, a double thermal shielding is employed to minimize the heat loss due to radia- tion, and the residual radiation loss is corrected by using an elaborate measurement conﬁguration.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Intermetallic IrSn4 binary crystallizes in three modiﬁca- tions; the low-temperature form, so-called α-IrSn4, adopts the trigonal IrGe4-type structure (space group P3121) [8], the high-temperature form, β-IrSn4 has the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) [9], and the high-pressure form, HP-IrSn4, possesses the orthorhombic PtSn4-type structure (space group Ccca) [10, 11]. To the best of our knowledge, only α-IrSn4 was reported to be a Pauli paramagnet and non-superconducting down to 2 K [8], whereas none of physical properties of β-IrSn4 and HP-IrSn4 have been reported yet.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the If β-IrSn4 is considered as a type-II superconductor then one can estimate the lower critical ﬁeld µ0Hc1 and the upper critical ﬁeld µ0Hc2. µ0Hc1 = 3 mT, if is deﬁned as the ﬁeld where the deviation of the M(H) curve from linearity in the Meissner state sets in, while µ0Hc2 = 6.5 mT at 0.5 K, determined as the intersection between linear interpolations of the magnetization in the superconducting and normal states.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto We studied structural and electrical properties under high pressure and low temperature for a S51/2 Heisen- berg two-leg ladder compound Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d. It showed a superconducting transition above 3 GPa with a maximum Tc of 13 K. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase survives at least up to 9 GPa and down to 7 K without decomposition or phase transition, indicating that it is responsible for the observed superconductivity.

Matsumoto However, Sr4Ca10Cu24O411d did not show superconductivity up to 8.5 GPa.61 As shown in Table I, both the a and c axis shrink in nearly the same percentage after the Ca substitution, whereas pressure induces, in the high-temperature region, more aniso- tropic intraplane shrinkage with a larger percentage along the c axis than along the a axis. Expecting direct observation of the Peierls transition, we carried out electron-diffraction measurements around 100 K, but no evidence for it was obtained.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto V. CONCLUSIONS We studied the x-ray diffraction and electrical resistivity in a composite crystal Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d under high pres- sure and low temperature to discuss the nature of the elec- tronic state and pressure-induced superconductivity from crystallographic aspects. The Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d phase sur- vives at least for P<9 GPa and T>7 K indicating that it is responsible for superconductivity observed only under high pressure.

Structural and electrical properties under high pressure for the superconducting spin-ladder system Sr0.4Ca13.6Cu24O411d M. Isobe, T. Ohta, M. Onoda, F. Izumi, S. Nakano, J. Q. Li,* Y. Matsui, and E. Takayama-Muromachi National Institute for Research in Inorganic Materials (NIRIM), 1-1 Namiki, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305 Japan T. Matsumoto Holes are doped into ladders from 1D chains via lo- cally formed Culadder 3d and Ochain 2p hybrid orbitals. The r-T curves in the normal state above 5 GPa obey a power law of tem- perature in the wide range of temperature between 7 and over 200 K, suggesting that carriers are mainly scattered by spin ﬂuctuation as well as in 2D high-Tc cuprates.

Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter PAPER Observation of superconductivity in the Matter 25 (2013) 155701 (8pp) doi:10.1088/0953-8984/25/15/155701 Observation of superconductivity in the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4 Vinh Hung Tran, Zbigniew Bukowski, Piotr Wi´sniewski, Lan Maria Tran and Andrzej J Zaleski Institute of Low Temperature and Structure Research, Polish Academy of Sciences, PO Box 1410, 50-950 Wrocław, Poland E-mail: V.H.Tran@int.pan.wroc.pl Received 4 January 2013, in ﬁnal form 18 February 2013 Published 25 March 2013 Online at stacks.iop.org/JPhysCM/25/155701 Abstract Low-temperature dc-magnetization, ac electrical resistivity and speciﬁc heat measurements were performed on single crystals of the intermetallic compound β-IrSn4. The compound crystallizes in the tetragonal MoSn4-type structure (space group I41/acd) and exhibits superconductivity below Tc = 0.9 ± 0.05 K. Further, the magnitude of the ratios 1Cp/(γnkBTc) = 1.29, 21/(kBTc) = 3.55 and of the electron–phonon coupling λe−ph = 0.5 imply that superconductivity in β-IrSn4 can be ascribed to a s-wave weak coupling regime.

Discussion and conclusions The ﬁrst picture which emerges from our measurements on single crystals of β-IrSn4 is that this binary intermetallic compound becomes superconducting below 0.9 ± 0.05 K. The zero-ﬁeld data listed in table 1 are in accordance with the conventional s-wave singlet pairing mechanism and would also provide a hint of either the type-I or type-II/1 superconductivity with a weak electron–phonon coupling.

Here we report the fabrication of large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals by chemical vapour deposition (CVD).

ARTICLES PUBLISHED ONLINE: 17 AUGUST 2015 | DOI: 10.1038/NMAT4374 Large-area high-quality 2D ultrathin Mo2C superconducting crystals Chuan Xu1†, Libin Wang2†, Zhibo Liu1, Long Chen1, Jingkun Guo2, Ning Kang2*, Xiu-Liang Ma1, Like other 2D crystals such as graphene, the lack of large-area high-quality 2D TMC crystals has hindered studies of their intrinsic properties. Here we develop a chemical vapour deposition (CVD) process, with methane as the carbon source and a Cu foil sitting on a Mo foil as the substrate at a temperature above 1,085 ◦C, to grow high-quality 2D ultrathin α-Mo2C crystals a few nanometres in thickness with lateral sizes of over 100 µm (see Methods).

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER Among them, only the Ti(1) site (2a in Wyckoff notation) displays an inversion center. It is of great importance that Re24Ti5 contains more than 80% heavy Re atoms which may promote a strong ASOC effect in its SC state.

Superconductor Science and Technology PAPER In this respect, Re24Ti5 would provide an opportunity to search for the existence of a mixture of spin singlet and spin triplet states in the SC phase of the noncentrosymmetric compounds. In this paper, we report on the synthesis and charac- terization of Re24Ti5, which exhibits a distinct bulk SC transition at Tc ≃5.8 K. Measurements of the magnetic, transport, and thermal properties have been performed.
